text: free at last
after two years of delays caused by the
pandemic the females angela ballon and
saeeda along with the male luga have
been released into the shamwari big cat
sanctuary in south africa born into
captivity they'd spent their lives
performing in a french traveling circus
transported around the country in
cramped trailers this journey began when
luger attacked the circus owner who then
decided they should go to an animal
welfare group
the wildlife charity the bourne free
foundation stepped in and a plan was
hatched to transport the lions to africa
early this week the foundation told bbc
breakfast what it would be like for the
animals to make what could be considered
a return home
just imagine every cell in their body is
going to feel at home because the warmth
of the sun the the
scents and sounds surrounding them um
but they will still have a a function
because the the born free foundation's
uh big cat rescue center is in chamois
uh in south africa and they have tens of
thousands of school children visiting
now the lines aren't on display they're
not right up there you might maybe have
to use binoculars to see them across an
enclosure but the kids will learn about
the role of lines in their ecosystem
so they'll be educating rather than
entertaining
they've never lived in the wild so would
be unlikely to survive if released
totally their three acre enclosure
filled with natural features is believed
to be the next best thing for these free
lions who are in many ways
coming home
john mcguire bbc news
